pros: FLexable work good work environment
cons: It gets busy at times

pros: Diverse workforce, certain departments have excellent leadership and flexible working environments.
cons: Certain departments and offices have had staff there for too long and they aren't interested in any changes or innovative developments for improved efficiency or operational success. HR department is not great.

pros: Nice students and flexible schedule
cons: No benefits, no raises, no full-time options for non-credit ESL instructors, only paid for hours teaching in classroom— doesn’t include lesson plans, grading, trainings, etc.

pros: Strong community along with a student 1st ethic.
cons: As part time work hours post pandemic have been cut dramatically. Things we were once included in are no longer an option.

review_title: They say they are student focused…but they are not.
pros: Several smaller campus sites available
cons: If you’re a newbie don’t expect to find anyone offering to help you get situated. It’s definitely a dog eat dog mentality. If you don’t conform to their norms, (which no one tells you what they are) you will be excommunicated without remorse.

review_title: Nepotism, unqualified employees, uneven pay, and lack of opportunities to move up.
pros: Job is fairly easy, but you do need to be on top of your workflow or it will back up. Some pretty nice people if you can find them throughout the staff.
cons: Many positions at CSCC are held by unqualified individuals who had connections within the college. Promotion from within only happens to those who have connections (i.e. myself and many co-workers have applied to positions within the college that we are very qualified for, but the people who usually end up getting it are friends or family of someone within the department, or they are coming from The Ohio State University). You can hold the same position as someone on campus, but they could make $20,000 more per year and you end up having to fix all of the work that they send you because they refuse to learn from past mistakes. Let's say you put together a competent raise proposal to try and get equal pay -- it'll be swept under the rug and since most directors don't talk with your average employee, you'll never really get a chance to find out why or what happened. Most accomplishments/achievements are completely ignored. You could save the college thousands or even tens of thousands of dollars a year by making a simple change that only affects 2-3 people, but you'll receive no more than a thank you email. You can do this multiple times, bringing your savings into the hundreds of thousands, but you'll still just get a thank you email or a "Cougar Paw." Meanwhile, someone created a cool little sticker to give out to students and they'll end up with employee of the month. Most departments treat their budget like it's Monopoly money. I kid you not the first few months I was with the college someone referred to it as this phrase. At the end of every fiscal year there is a spending spree throughout the college because, and I quote people who have been with the college for 2-3 decades, "If you don't spend it, you don't get it next time." They continue this cycle every year, stock piling items that end up being thrown out or replaced the following year despite the items being perfectly fine, but you know, they gotta spend that money or they don't get it back. Despite the budgets being wasted, the tuition rate continues to increase, negatively affecting the students.

pros: I really enjoyed my time teaching here. The full time faculty were always happy to help you out.
cons: None. It was a great part time job.

pros: -Caring team -Amazing Kids -Works for difficult schedules
cons: -None at all, but I need at least 5 words.

pros: Great mission, great benefits. Amazing people.
cons: High volume of work for the pay.

review_title: Not a company with growth opportunities
pros: Holidays covered and free tuition
cons: Double standards and favoritisms, lack of management and leadership skills, incompetent management, no opportunity to grow, low pay, discrimination and sexual harassment

job_title: Math Department Chair in Columbus, OH
pros: No longer there. I never have to go back.
cons: I can’t think of anything other than it paid my bills.

job_title: IT Support Technician in Columbus, OH
pros: Good Pay Easy Work 29 Hours a week
cons: It's a help desk, what more can you expect?

pros: - Great training for the role - Good variety of projects - Good leadership
cons: - Work-life balance can be challenging during peak times

pros: Great environment and people in general
cons: None for me for the duration of employment

pros:
-Kind and efficient department (DDG)
-Ability to teach online
-Relaxed atmosphere
-Strong curriculum
-Just began offering adjuncts a small life insurance policy
cons: -If student numbers are low, courses can be dropped (I do not rely on this position as my primary source of income)

pros: Good student population. Easy access..
cons: Pandemic hurt enrollment. Less classes available

review_title: Apply if you like helping and talking to people :)
pros: Healthy work environment Free food Fun events Work-life balance
cons: 20 hours maximum per week

pros: Management was supportive and consistent hours
cons: Benefits were scarce and the job was fairly pointless.

pros: Flexible schedule, friendly work environment, free tuition.
cons: Slow to get projects started or new ideas implemented.

pros: Great community! The President and team are transparent with school direction and keeping staff and faculty in the know. Student success is the mission of all teams. I am proud to be working at a place that is paving the way for all students to find school an affordable option. The promise of free first year of school for Columbus City students is a phenomenal opportunity. It's a community that cares top to bottom.
cons: They only con now is Covid and the hustle and bustle absent from the school with many students learning from home. I miss them on campus.

pros: I have the best colleagues who care deeply about higher education and student support and success. The college allows academic freedom and support faculty in their scholarly efforts.
cons: Lower pay than someone with an advanced degree could make in industry.

pros: I enjoy my time at CSCC
cons: finding opportunities can be a challenge. Knowing the right people seems to be more important than the job you do.

pros: A great place to work, if you are flexible..
cons: You can only get assigned a good schedule if you are very available. Semester schedules come out only one week before the semester starts.

pros: Nice environment to work at
cons: This is not a remote work place

pros: Good working environment, union representation. On site fitness facilities and food options.
cons: Human resources department is frequently unhelpful. As an instructor, you may be asked to teach at far-away off-campus locations. No guarantee of employment beyond the original 3 year contract.

job_title: Learning %26 Support Specialist II in Columbus, OH
pros: Clean and Safe working environment. Responsive supervisors and directors. Helpful coworkers.
cons: Parking can be difficult, because there are often students mixed in to the employee parking lot.

review_title: Good place to start a career
pros: Family atmosphere depending upon department
cons: Can be hard to find upward mobility within the institution.

pros: I've been here for nearly 24 years. The College truly cares about its students and its employees. Throughout the past year and a half, our guiding principles have included flexibility and compassion, both for students and employees -- without compromising our educational mission.
cons: As with any public institution, pay tends to be lower than similar positions in the corporate world. However, the educational mission makes it worthwhile.

job_title: Learning and Development in Columbus, OH
pros:
Positive team environment
Great place to start career
cons: Have not experienced any cons

pros: Good opportunities, Administration cares about staff, good benefits, stable employment. very inclusive and progressive culture.
cons: There aren't any cons I can think of that is unique to CSCC that isn't true of working in education in general, such as, you'll probably make more money and advance quicker in the private sector but it's still a great place to grow a career and earn a living.

pros: The organization has supported employees throughout the pandemic by allowing remote work, additional days for paid personal leave, and supportive mental health resources.
cons: Management of individual offices/departments can be lacking.

review_title: Diverse Campus / Not Competetative Pay for Interpreters
job_title: Sign Language Interpreter in Columbus, OH
pros: Diverse, walkable campus, continuous learning from students and instructors, most instructors are fairly accommodating for deaf students, very motivated students, space to go for down time, food on campus, can work as little or much as availability allows per semester
cons: Not a lot of room for growth, pay is not competitive with the field & little room to negotiate pay, some instructors seem underqualified and are not sensitive to accommodations for students or will say “well, I tried”, to paid for downtime between classes, scheduling is a mess and last-minute due to students changing their schedules last minute

pros:
They have really great management.

Good Hours.

Good Culture.

Pay is lower that you would expect.

pros: It is possible to have job where you go to school!
cons: Once you graduate you have to find somewhere else to work, last I knew.

pros:

pros: pay is descent and job is not hard
cons: Nothing bad noticed in this job

pros: Great place to work at CSCC
cons: N/A No cons for CSCC

pros: The people, environment, good at adjusting to WFH

pros: Most students were motivated to learn

pros: Friendly environment, Helpful staff, give room for innovation and creativity, good communication
cons: no enough salary, no benefits, and no constant hours provided more organization needed, for different instructor to provide same output to students,

pros: I believe there is something great at the College as a whole.  The segment of students, I believe are the wave of the future and will be the core of tomorrow's workforce.  Thanksgiving week and Christmas/New Year's shutdown!
cons: There needs to be a holistic review of the mid-level management.  Just because someone has an online master's or doctorate does not make them a leader or proper manager.  Executive level should see why good people are leaving.  They don't want to play mind games or continue to be beat down.  The manipulation, control, mental oppression really sucks the life out of the dept.  Zero professional development or true guidance/betterment from this "director".  These opinions are only of one department/office and should not be seen as a reflection of the College as a whole.

review_title: Good Place To Start... But Not Stay and Become Stagnant
job_title: Front-end Web Developer and Graphic Designer in Brisbane
pros:
Great Benefits: Health, Dental, Vision; Paid Time Off; Sick Leave; $8000 Educational Reimbursement Stipend towards post-graduate work; Parking.

Laid back work environment.
cons:
Laid back work environment breathes stagnation and complacency. Many employees come and stay until retirement... Working just hard enough to get by, in an environment that is fairly stable... Which is great for them, but QUITE DIFFICULT for more-driven people to stay passionate and motivated, and move up the ladder.

Promotions rarely happen. If and when they do, it seems to be based on seniority, rather than who is actually doing a remarkable job... OR, if you happen to brown-nose with the boss!

review_title: I wish I had more positive things to say
pros: There are some really great people who work at Columbus State who work really hard and care about each other and students. The work-life balance is wonderful.
cons: It's disturbing how outdated the college is. You would think a college is a place where new ideas, fresh perspectives, diversity, and healthy debates are the norm, but that isn't the case on the administrative side of the institution. Many great ideas for advancing the college have been shut down or paused and lost in the practice of consensus management and never-ending vetting. People are afraid to make decisions, so they don't. OSU is referenced in too many meetings, keeping CS from becoming a truly unique college. Executives are out of touch with employees, and they don't communicate or ask for feedback. Leaders need to walk the talk of being in a mission driven institution.

pros:
The students  ,faculty  and some staff are what makes it bearable.
The pay is not bad, there is a lot of favoritism  at review time.
cons: Administration didn't think that some one working there for more than 5 years was flexible. A lot of supervisors have no training in supervising. Communication is the only what you need to know  to do your and the nice to know that will not effect the outcome of a decision.  If you are inherited. There are some people that can get away with doing the minimum

pros:
People.  Some of the best people I know are my current coworkers.
Good hours.
Decent office.
Like my current team
cons:
There doesn't seem to be a clear plan at times.
Constant projects that don't seem to amount to anything.
CIO is a consultant who doesn't seem to care much about anything but getting to the end of their contract so they can split after upending everyone and everything.
No accountability in many areas.  Sr. Management constantly battling for their fiefdoms.  No desire to actually make things better.
Everything seems to be all talk with no clear direction once the meeting (after meeting after meeting) is over.

pros: Collaboration is the key to working within education. For the most part, Columbus State administrators do their best to find ways to serve students and eliminate silos. That is mainly because the people that work for Columbus State love their students and love the work they do to help them.
cons: There is minimal opportunity to advance. People tend to stay in their position for a long time regardless of whether they do outstanding work or sub-par work. There is also very little wiggle room in terms of salary, bonuses, or raises.

pros: The good thing is that you can choose your schedule in the Math department.  Those with highest seniority get to choose first and so on.  Then you can try to change your schedule with someone in the department if you like.
cons: The downside to the Math department is you just about have to be from one of the Ohio universities to get hired or you have to be an adjunct in the department and apply for a higher position.  Standard Deviation = 0.

pros: Overall I had a wonderful experience being a tutor for ESL after school communities. It's a wonderful program that provides help to students whose parents do not speak English.  My experience was amazing, and I'd love for them to continue provided these services to children all over the Columbus.
cons: I think that tutors should be paid a bit more. We do everything a teacher does, only thing different is that we teach after school hours. But, the lesson planning, teaching, and class room management is all the same as how a regular school classroom would operate.

review_title: Rewarding and Invaluable Entry-Level Teaching Experience
pros: You'll get valuable experience creating lesson plans, administering exams, managing classrooms and developing your skills in a comfortable classroom with technology that works.
cons: Front line supervision has deteriorated, and there is surprisingly little professional development.  You may feel very alone in your teaching job - until you get the first critical email about a missing middle initial on an attendance spreadsheet.

review_title: One of learning. I don't know any organization that's perfect.
pros: Co-workers, and the job itself is satisfying.
cons: Lack of communication and the feeling that new leadership comes across, maybe unintentional, as being out of touch with common working people.

review_title: If you have to adjunct, it
pros:
The pay was good, for what it was. The people were very nice, and for the most part, really seemed to care about the student experience.  From my experiences at other community colleges, another big pro is how this college is run.

Doing paperwork, getting hired, getting paid all went very smoothly. It's an excellent summer job for a graduate student, or for any qualified person looking to make a bit of extra money.
cons: It was still an adjunct position, so it would be very difficult to live on the wages received from CSCC alone.

review_title: A good place to work over-all.
pros:
Great Pay
Some Autonomy
Great Technology
Columbus State has good retirement because it is part of the STRS.  Great support from IT department, building maintenance, etc.
cons: Hard on adjuncts;  Need more training about policies and procedures; Hard to move up because people stay in the their positions for such a long period of time.  No benefits;  Seven hours of sick time every couple of quarters.  If you don't use it, you lose it.  No other benefits.

job_title: Adjunct Accounting Professor in Columbus, OH
pros: They gave me a place to figure out if I wanted to teach as a career, and when I didn't, where I could make some extra money and have fun teaching something I love.
cons: Some programs have very little flexibility for the instructor so you can make changes.  I don't believe this is Columbus State alone, it probably has something to do with transfer credit for the students.

pros: The Columbus State Community College is a wonderful transition between college transfers, and is a apprentice icon within developing a college intern's skills and knowledge concerning these skills, knowledge, and on-job training advantages to possess!
cons: Columbus State Community College is more geared to the entering young-adulthood generation. So, if your more in-depth to a atmosphere of quality learning and already have children turning into young-adults, this would be more ideal for your young-adults in a higher learning education environment.

review_title: A good place to work while studying for a new career
pros: Full-time employees can take classes for free
cons: Depending on which department you work in, there may be little opportunity for advancement. Also, you may find that how hard you work is not reflected in reviews or bonuses. In my particular department, my boss was consistently instructed not to give any above-average reviews, regardless of performance.

pros: The position was a great learning experience and it really helped me to build my resume. I would recommend for any students to get a work study job.
cons: None that I can think of. This was a very relaxed position and I was able to learn and continue to build skills and add to my resume

review_title: Ok job. Above average pay, good benefits. Top heavy management structure. Difficult to advance without personal contacts
pros: Above average pay. Great benefits including health care and discounted/free tuition for employee and family. Great employees, good work atmosphere. Good place to pick up skills and experience for entry level workers.
cons: Top heavy management makes advancing difficult. Culture varies by department. Some departments have no positions between entry level and upper management.

review_title: Great school for people interested in teaching
pros: Good part time subliment to high school teaching, totally different learning interaction provides a different kind of reward, mostly hard working students, good pay, math department run well
cons: Not as much room for creative teaching as HS, not much opportunity to advance or progress into full time

review_title: I would say my experience was poor.
pros: Close to home; many satellite campuses; good working hours; free parking; access to email and internet; direct deposit for pay.
cons: Dept. too large; no opportunity for advancement; computer systems out of date; pay too low; class sizes too big; lack of feedback

review_title: work-study job at the IT Student Help Desk
job_title: Help Desk Technician (Work Study) in Columbus, OH
pros: Relaxed work environment, good coworkers, lots of downtime and fairly simple responsibilities, spent a lot of my time doing homework for class
cons: The only cons are inherent to the job - helping people with their computers can be incredibly frustrating.  Many people are mad at you before they meet you, and very few people appreciate your time.

review_title: Great Place to Work While Getting a Degree... Advancement within is frowned upon. Not a career, more of a job.
pros: Great co-workers, management was understanding with scheduling, work delegation.
cons: Not a place to hold a career, but a job.

review_title: Hasn't lived up to the hype
pros: Steady employment, lots of good people to work with
cons: Too much micromanaging, pay is well below local market, tuition reimbursement process is a real headache

pros: Do whatever you want whenever you want.  Decent pay.  You can decide how much you want to work and when, since nothing really important is ever going on
cons: BORING.  Lousy management. No forward progress.  Middle managers are great, but upper management is a joke.

job_title: Columbus Testing Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: Location is close to central ohio.
cons: Below average pay. Management is out of touch with employees below them.

job_title: Learning Support Specialist in Columbus, OH
pros: Positive community. Relaxed environment. Students are great overall.
cons: Can't work more than 29 hours a week if part-time. Less if adjuncting. Sometimes there aren't enough hours to go around dependent on student enrollment. Traffic and parking at main campus can be problematic.

pros: love the work and the people
cons: Office Associates are extremely underpaid in comparison to same job at other colleges

pros: As an adjunct faculty member, CSCC provides instructors with a master template/LMS from which to work. The courses are organized and sequenced in an efficient manner.
cons: I was hired 4 days before the course started, not giving me much time to prepare.

pros: Great culture of diversity,  education, and excellence.  Low turnover and great benefits.
cons: Salaries are below market averages.   Low turnover means very slow and limited  advancement potential.

review_title: Great People, Great Place to work!

Great Supportive Mathematics Department Personnel
Many opportunities for training and professional development
Lead instructors communicate often and respond promptly to questions and requests
cons:
Usual adjunct pay
Lots of competition for full-time positions

pros: This position was both challenging and rewarding.  I helped connect students to employment opportunities in their field of education.  I think the program was/is great, and has a wonderful impact on the community.
cons: Nothing to share at this time.

pros: Great facilities and faculty and programing.
cons: Focuses very heavily on degree seeking students...many of us are looking for the skills more then the sheet of paper.

pros:
Great ideas
Staff want to help students
cons:
Inefficiencies all across campus-- students get bounced from office to office
Workload distribution is out of balance-- some work extra hours with too much to do, while others have little to do each day

review_title: A good place for part-time work
pros: Good supervisors who work very hard, flexible hours, great students.
cons: No benefits. Hard to get enough work to make ends meet if you were the main provider of your household.

pros: benefits, campus is beautiful, continued education
cons: no advancement, have to wait for someone to retire

job_title: Adjunct Nursing Instructor in Columbus, OH
pros: They have wonderful staff, great students, and the pay and benefits are great. Pay into the state teachers retirement even if you are an adjunct.
cons: Parking is difficult especially during fall semester.

pros: Good community ethos, opportunity to grow, great atmosphere on the campus. College mission is very noble, helping students succeed and thrive.

Working with students of diverse backgrounds.
Commitment to higher education and community. 
Compensation.
Leadership.

Internal growth opportunities.
Colleagues' fear of change.

review_title: The staff and students I worked with. Small campus.
pros: Nice atmosphere, flexibility, supportive, friendly staff
cons: Own office to do work

pros: They are committed to student learning and allow flexibility in teaching styles.
cons: No enough classes offered.

pros: The students, staff and learning

pros: Benefits, Collaboration, Empowerment, Work/life balance, Educational Opportunities
cons: Lack of career growth and top heavy organization

pros: A degree obtained here results in being qualified for employment.
cons: Hard to get a start in the workplace without the aforementioned degree.

pros: Flexibility, tuition reimbursement, co-workers, campus, vicinity to downtown.
cons: Use of consultants for many internal issues. High turnover of executives.

pros: Great support, Kind and Knowledgeable staff

pros: The hourly rate was phenomenal

pros: Really do care about students and their success.

pros: Collegial staff, nice department chair, fun students, nice campus, decent parking, good technology
